notesStmt.note: Letter is dated 1895; letter of September 23, 1895, written by Cody to Beck from Patterson, New Jersey, refers to Cody having just met Salsbury and Beck. Nathan "Nate" Salsbury (1846-1902) was an actor and head of the Troubadours, a traveling stock company which would eventually tour Europe and the United States. After Cody met Salsbury the "Wild West" show venture would begin and in 1884 he would become a partner as well as Vice-President and Manager of Buffalo Bill's Wild West until his death in 1902. George Bleistein (1861-1918) from Buffalo, New York, owned the Courier Printing Company and provided printing for Buffalo Bill's Wild West. Bleistein was also a partner and director in the Shoshone Irrigation Company.

div1.note:
The Buffalo Bill Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World. Col. W. F. Cody (Buffalo Bill), President.
Nate Salsbury, Vice-Pres't and Manager.
John M. Burke, . . . General Manager.
Albert E. Scheible, . . . Business Manager.
Jule Keen, . . . Treasurer.
div1.p: I will see Salsbury & Bleistein tomorrow. But will send new route cards2 to night

back.note: Note 1: On September 21, 1895, Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Newburgh, New York. The year is not inscribed by Cody but subsequent correspondence confirms 1895. Cody wrote to Beck on September 23, 1895 (CSS00451), inscribed from nearby Paterson, New Jersey, and referring to Cody having just met Salsbury and Bleistein.
Note 2: Route cards were imprinted with BBWW tour schedules and distributed to the public.
